systems.title: Simulated Naval Systems
systems.desc: Understand the thermal/mechanical physics and operation behind each vessel subsystem.
systems.engineDesc1: The propulsion heart of the ship. This heavy diesel system is mainly affected by two variables simulated volumetrically and inertially:
systems.engineLi1: Revolutions (RPM): Rotational speed. Normal values are around 1000 RPM. Exceeding 1200 RPM subjects the engine to stress.
systems.engineLi2: Temperature (°C): Increases slowly and gradually, simulating the thermal inertia of the engine block. Poor cooling will cause temperatures to spike above 100°C, forcing a thermal relay trip to prevent block meltdown.
systems.engineRisk: Risk: An abrupt cutoff will leave the vessel adrift without propulsion.
systems.auxDesc1: Responsible for providing alternating current (AC) electrical power to the entire ship infrastructure.
systems.auxLi1: Voltage (V): Oscillates sinusoidally seeking to maintain a stable 220V/400V depending on the load. Unstable voltage will blow fuses.
systems.auxLi2: Frequency (Hz): Stable at 50/60Hz. Represents the integrity of the generated magnetic wave. If poles are magnetically overloaded, frequency varies prior to system collapse.
systems.auxRisk: Risk: Generator failure causes a "Blackout", shutting down main panels.
systems.bilgeDesc1: Manages and keeps the bottom and bilge of the vessel dry from constant ocean and internal water filtration.
systems.bilgeLi1: Water Level (cm): Monitors how flooded the lower chamber is. Pumps extract water automatically at a fixed rate (e.g., 0.5 cm per second).
systems.bilgeRisk: The simulation injects a constant residual volume. If the pump is disabled, the level will rise, simulating an internal leak. Exceeding the maximum threshold poses an imminent risk to vessel buoyancy.
systems.radarDesc1: Provides "situational awareness" (visibility in nautical miles), preventing collisions.
systems.radarLi1: Range (nm): Range of returned echoes. A radio frequency jamming attack can dramatically truncate this visibility.
systems.radarLi2: Sweep Frequency (GHz): Sensitivity of the device. A drop indicates degradation of the magneto-resonant emitter.
systems.steeringDesc1: Hydraulic-mechanical control of the aft rudder blade that steers the ship.
systems.steeringLi1: Hydraulic Pressure (bar): Requires over 120 bar to be steerable. Pressure drops indicate pipe leaks and will cause steering delays from the bridge.
systems.steeringLi2: Rudder Angle (°): The actual position of the deflector.
systems.fireDesc1: The extinguishing system using a sprinkler network or chemical agents.
systems.fireProtocol: Emergency Protocol: Fire detection automatically triggers electrical isolation of the affected system. Requires immediate human supervision.
systems.fireLi1: Manifold Pressure (bar): Similar to steering, the network must be constantly pressurized, ready to deploy.
systems.fireLi2: Smoke and Temperature Detectors: These are the trigger variables; upon rising, solenoid valves open, expelling the agent throughout the affected chamber.

manual.title: User Manual | Interfaces
manual.dashDesc1: Represents the top-down perspective of the naval unit. Implements an interactive hotspots system:
manual.dashLi2: Gray Indicators (Inactive): Manual system deactivation. This can compromise dependent functions (e.g., disabling the bilge causes flooding).
manual.dashLi3: Red Indicators (High rate): Disconnection state (TRIPPED). Indicates a critical failure or detected intrusion.
manual.dashDesc2: Hovering over a point displays an opaque card with live telemetry; clicking it navigates to its command console.
manual.simDesc1: The Control or Telemetry Room provides real-time graphs of all subsystems updating at 2 Hz.
manual.simDesc2: You can manually force anomalies on these graphs by injecting "Brute Force" or "Signal Injection" via the buttons below the graph. This temporarily corrupts the sensors, simulating a cyber threat or physical sensor/IO failure.
manual.dataDesc1: The ship's flight recorder and logbook. Features 3 critical divisions:
manual.dataLi1: Normal Reports: Every 20 seconds, the computer captures the ship's nominal state and encrypts it in silent green logs.
manual.dataLi2: Warnings (Yellow): If a sensor hits a `90%` threshold of its maximum limit (e.g., engine temp nearing 97°C), the system interrupts the 20-second clock and forces an immediate log injection. Isolate these logs using the yellow button to preemptively spot issues.
manual.dataLi3: Criticals (Red): Logged at the exact moment a relay trips due to a sensor reaching its absolute maximum limit (e.g., exactly 100°C). These are failure and collapse records.

trouble.title: Emergency Troubleshooting
trouble.subtitle: Operations and response manual (SOP) for NAVALSEC system anomalies.
trouble.q1: Why have global red alerts (TRIPPED) triggered?
trouble.a1: A `TRIPPED` state implies an unscheduled emergency shutdown. The system "broke" the circuit because one of the sensors breached the equipment's survivability threshold (Safe Max / Safe Min). This prevented an engine block fire or a generator exploding from a sustained short circuit.
trouble.q2: How do I recover my system after a TRIPPED state?
trouble.a2Li1: By default, the simulation's onboard software agent will automatically rearm the thermal/magnetic relay after 5-7 seconds, treating it as a transient fault. You'll see the view return to green.
trouble.a2Li2: If the fault condition persists (e.g., a critical unevacuated flood or an active high-frequency spoofing vector), the system will re-enter the TRIPPED state immediately, generating persistent notifications.
trouble.a2Li3: Manual Reset: Access the Injection panel to neutralize the attack vector, or manually reconfigure the relay from the Control Room once sensor readings normalize.
trouble.q3: What does an 'Unknown' IP mean during a Cyberattack?
trouble.a3: The log collector audits all requests against a trusted list. If a packet is detected whose IP signature doesn't match the originating subsystem, the firewall logs the event as an intrusion. These spoofed IP addresses can be monitored in the detailed Logbook.
